member.summary: The window has a maximize button. Cannot be combined with the WS_EX_CONTEXTHELP style. The WS_SYSMENU style must also be specified.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.User32.WindowStyles.WS_MINIMIZE
member.summary: The window is initially minimized.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.User32.WindowStyles.WS_MINIMIZEBOX
member.summary: The window has a minimize button. Cannot be combined with the WS_EX_CONTEXTHELP style. The WS_SYSMENU style must also be specified.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.User32.WindowStyles.WS_OVERLAPPED
member.summary: The window is an overlapped window. An overlapped window has a title bar and a border.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.User32.WindowStyles.WS_OVERLAPPEDWINDOW
member.summary: The window is an overlapped window.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.User32.WindowStyles.WS_POPUP
member.summary: The window is a pop-up window. This style cannot be used with the WS_CHILD style.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.User32.WindowStyles.WS_POPUPWINDOW
member.summary: The window is a pop-up window. The WS_CAPTION and WS_POPUPWINDOW styles must be combined to make the window menu visible.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.User32.WindowStyles.WS_SIZEFRAME
member.summary: The window has a sizing border.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.User32.WindowStyles.WS_SYSMENU
member.summary: The window has a window menu on its title bar. The WS_CAPTION style must also be specified.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.User32.WindowStyles.WS_TABSTOP
member.summary: The window is a control that can receive the keyboard focus when the user presses the TAB key. Pressing the TAB key changes the keyboard focus to the next control with the WS_TABSTOP style. You can turn this style on and off to change dialog box navigation. To change this style after a window has been created, use the SetWindowLong function. For user-created windows and modeless dialogs to work with tab stops, alter the message loop to call the IsDialogMessage function.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.User32.WindowStyles.WS_VISIBLE
member.summary: The window is initially visible. This style can be turned on and off by using the ShowWindow or SetWindowPos function.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.User32.WindowStyles.WS_VSCROLL
member.summary: The window has a vertical scroll bar.

member.name: T:Vanara.PInvoke.User32.WindowStylesEx
member.summary: Extended window styles.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.User32.WindowStylesEx.WS_EX_ACCEPTFILES
member.summary: Specifies a window that accepts drag-drop files.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.User32.WindowStylesEx.WS_EX_APPWINDOW
member.summary: Forces a top-level window onto the taskbar when the window is visible.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.User32.WindowStylesEx.WS_EX_CLIENTEDGE
member.summary: Specifies a window that has a border with a sunken edge.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.User32.WindowStylesEx.WS_EX_COMPOSITED
member.summary: Specifies a window that paints all descendants in bottom-to-top painting order using double-buffering. This cannot be used if the window has a class style of either CS_OWNDC or CS_CLASSDC. This style is not supported in Windows 2000.
member.remarks: With WS_EX_COMPOSITED set, all descendants of a window get bottom-to-top painting order using double-buffering. Bottom-to-top painting order allows a descendent window to have translucency (alpha) and transparency (color-key) effects, but only if the descendent window also has the WS_EX_TRANSPARENT bit set. Double-buffering allows the window and its descendents to be painted without flicker.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.User32.WindowStylesEx.WS_EX_CONTEXTHELP
member.summary: Specifies a window that includes a question mark in the title bar. When the user clicks the question mark, the cursor changes to a question mark with a pointer. If the user then clicks a child window, the child receives a WM_HELP message. The child window should pass the message to the parent window procedure, which should call the WinHelp function using the HELP_WM_HELP command. The Help application displays a pop-up window that typically contains help for the child window. WS_EX_CONTEXTHELP cannot be used with the WS_MAXIMIZEBOX or WS_MINIMIZEBOX styles.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.User32.WindowStylesEx.WS_EX_CONTROLPARENT
member.summary: Specifies a window which contains child windows that should take part in dialog box navigation. If this style is specified, the dialog manager recurses into children of this window when performing navigation operations such as handling the TAB key, an arrow key, or a keyboard mnemonic.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.User32.WindowStylesEx.WS_EX_DLGMODALFRAME
member.summary: Specifies a window that has a double border.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.User32.WindowStylesEx.WS_EX_LAYERED
member.summary: Specifies a window that is a layered window. This cannot be used for child windows or if the window has a class style of either CS_OWNDC or CS_CLASSDC.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.User32.WindowStylesEx.WS_EX_LAYOUTRTL
member.summary: Specifies a window with the horizontal origin on the right edge. Increasing horizontal values advance to the left. The shell language must support reading-order alignment for this to take effect.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.User32.WindowStylesEx.WS_EX_LEFT
member.summary: Specifies a window that has generic left-aligned properties. This is the default.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.User32.WindowStylesEx.WS_EX_LEFTSCROLLBAR
member.summary: Specifies a window with the vertical scroll bar (if present) to the left of the client area. The shell language must support reading-order alignment for this to take effect.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.User32.WindowStylesEx.WS_EX_LTRREADING
member.summary: Specifies a window that displays text using left-to-right reading-order properties. This is the default.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.User32.WindowStylesEx.WS_EX_MDICHILD
member.summary: Specifies a multiple-document interface (MDI) child window.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.User32.WindowStylesEx.WS_EX_NOACTIVATE
member.summary: Specifies a top-level window created with this style does not become the foreground window when the user clicks it. The system does not bring this window to the foreground when the user minimizes or closes the foreground window. The window does not appear on the taskbar by default. To force the window to appear on the taskbar, use the WS_EX_APPWINDOW style. To activate the window, use the SetActiveWindow or SetForegroundWindow function.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.User32.WindowStylesEx.WS_EX_NOINHERITLAYOUT
member.summary: Specifies a window which does not pass its window layout to its child windows.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.User32.WindowStylesEx.WS_EX_NOPARENTNOTIFY
member.summary: Specifies that a child window created with this style does not send the WM_PARENTNOTIFY message to its parent window when it is created or destroyed.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.User32.WindowStylesEx.WS_EX_OVERLAPPEDWINDOW
member.summary: Specifies an overlapped window.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.User32.WindowStylesEx.WS_EX_PALETTEWINDOW
member.summary: Specifies a palette window, which is a modeless dialog box that presents an array of commands.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.User32.WindowStylesEx.WS_EX_RIGHT
member.summary: Specifies a window that has generic "right-aligned" properties. This depends on the window class. The shell language must support reading-order alignment for this to take effect. Using the WS_EX_RIGHT style has the same effect as using the SS_RIGHT (static), ES_RIGHT (edit), and BS_RIGHT/BS_RIGHTBUTTON (button) control styles.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.User32.WindowStylesEx.WS_EX_RIGHTSCROLLBAR
member.summary: Specifies a window with the vertical scroll bar (if present) to the right of the client area. This is the default.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.User32.WindowStylesEx.WS_EX_RTLREADING
member.summary: Specifies a window that displays text using right-to-left reading-order properties. The shell language must support reading-order alignment for this to take effect.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.User32.WindowStylesEx.WS_EX_STATICEDGE
member.summary: Specifies a window with a three-dimensional border style intended to be used for items that do not accept user input.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.User32.WindowStylesEx.WS_EX_TOOLWINDOW
member.summary: Specifies a window that is intended to be used as a floating toolbar. A tool window has a title bar that is shorter than a normal title bar, and the window title is drawn using a smaller font. A tool window does not appear in the taskbar or in the dialog that appears when the user presses ALT+TAB. If a tool window has a system menu, its icon is not displayed on the title bar. However, you can display the system menu by right-clicking or by typing ALT+SPACE.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.User32.WindowStylesEx.WS_EX_TOPMOST
member.summary: Specifies a window that should be placed above all non-topmost windows and should stay above them, even when the window is deactivated. To add or remove this style, use the SetWindowPos function.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.User32.WindowStylesEx.WS_EX_TRANSPARENT
member.summary: Specifies a window that should not be painted until siblings beneath the window (that were created by the same thread) have been painted. The window appears transparent because the bits of underlying sibling windows have already been painted. To achieve transparency without these restrictions, use the SetWindowRgn function.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.User32.WindowStylesEx.WS_EX_WINDOWEDGE
member.summary: Specifies a window that has a border with a raised edge.

member.name: T:Vanara.PInvoke.User32.FVIRT
member.summary: Flags used by .

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.User32.FVIRT.FVIRTKEY
member.summary: The key member specifies a virtual-key code. If this flag is not specified, key is assumed to specify a character code.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.User32.FVIRT.FNOINVERT
member.summary: No top-level menu item is highlighted when the accelerator is used. If this flag is not specified, a top-level menu item will be highlighted, if possible, when the accelerator is used. This attribute is obsolete and retained only for backward compatibility with resource files designed for 16-bit Windows.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.User32.FVIRT.FSHIFT
member.summary: The SHIFT key must be held down when the accelerator key is pressed.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.User32.FVIRT.FCONTROL
member.summary: The CTRL key must be held down when the accelerator key is pressed.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.User32.FVIRT.FALT
member.summary: The ALT key must be held down when the accelerator key is pressed.

member.name: M:Vanara.PInvoke.User32.CopyAcceleratorTable(Vanara.PInvoke.HACCEL,Vanara.PInvoke.User32.ACCEL[],System.Int32)
member.summary: Copies the specified accelerator table. This function is used to obtain the accelerator-table data that corresponds to an accelerator-table handle, or to determine the size of the accelerator-table data.

param.name: hAccelSrc
param.para: Type: HACCEL
A handle to the accelerator table to copy.

param.name: lpAccelDst
param.para: Type: LPACCEL
An array of ACCEL structures that receives the accelerator-table information.

param.name: cAccelEntries
param.para: Type: int
The number of ACCEL structures to copy to the buffer pointed to by the lpAccelDst parameter.

returns.para: Type: int
If lpAccelDst is NULL, the return value specifies the number of accelerator-table entries in the original table. Otherwise, it specifies the number of accelerator-table entries that were copied.

member.name: M:Vanara.PInvoke.User32.CreateAcceleratorTable(Vanara.PInvoke.User32.ACCEL[],System.Int32)
member.summary: Creates an accelerator table.

param.name: paccel
param.para: Type: LPACCEL
An array of ACCEL structures that describes the accelerator table.

param.name: cAccel
param.para: Type: int
The number of ACCEL structures in the array. This must be within the range 1 to 32767 or the function will fail.

returns.para: Type: HACCEL
If the function succeeds, the return value is the handle to the created accelerator table; otherwise, it is NULL. To get extended error information, call GetLastError.

remarks.para: Before an application closes, it can use the DestroyAcceleratorTable function to destroy any accelerator tables that it created by using the CreateAcceleratorTable function.
Examples
For an example, see Creating User Editable Accelerators.

member.name: M:Vanara.PInvoke.User32.DestroyAcceleratorTable(Vanara.PInvoke.HACCEL)
member.summary: Destroys an accelerator table.

param.name: hAccel
param.para: Type: HACCEL
A handle to the accelerator table to be destroyed. This handle must have been created by a call to the CreateAcceleratorTable or LoadAccelerators function.

returns.para: Type: BOOL

If the function succeeds, the return value is nonzero. However, if the table has been loaded more than one call to LoadAccelerators, the function will return a nonzero value only when DestroyAcceleratorTable has been called an equal number of times.
If the function fails, the return value is zero.

member.name: M:Vanara.PInvoke.User32.LoadAccelerators(Vanara.PInvoke.HINSTANCE,System.String)
member.summary: Loads the specified accelerator table.

param.name: hInstance
param.para: Type: HINSTANCE
A handle to the module whose executable file contains the accelerator table to be loaded.

param.name: lpTableName
param.para: Type: LPCTSTR

The name of the accelerator table to be loaded. Alternatively, this parameter can specify the resource identifier of an accelerator-table resource in the low-order word and zero in the high-order word. To create this value, use the MAKEINTRESOURCE macro.

returns.para: Type: HACCEL
If the function succeeds, the return value is a handle to the loaded accelerator table.
If the function fails, the return value is NULL. To get extended error information, call GetLastError.

remarks.para: If the accelerator table has not yet been loaded, the function loads it from the specified executable file.
Accelerator tables loaded from resources are freed automatically when the application terminates.
Examples
For an example, see Creating Accelerators for Font Attributes.

member.name: M:Vanara.PInvoke.User32.TranslateAccelerator(Vanara.PInvoke.HWND,Vanara.PInvoke.HACCEL,Vanara.PInvoke.MSG@)
member.summary: Processes accelerator keys for menu commands. The function translates a WM_KEYDOWN or WM_SYSKEYDOWN message to a WM_COMMAND or WM_SYSCOMMAND message (if there is an entry for the key in the specified accelerator table) and then sends the WM_COMMAND or WM_SYSCOMMAND message directly to the specified window procedure. TranslateAccelerator does not return until the window procedure has processed the message.

param.name: hWnd
param.para: Type: HWND
A handle to the window whose messages are to be translated.

param.name: hAccTable
param.para: Type: HACCEL
A handle to the accelerator table. The accelerator table must have been loaded by a call to the LoadAccelerators function or created by a call to the CreateAcceleratorTable function.

param.name: lpMsg
param.para: Type: LPMSG
A pointer to an MSG structure that contains message information retrieved from the calling thread's message queue using the GetMessage or PeekMessage function.

returns.para: Type: int
If the function succeeds, the return value is nonzero.
If the function fails, the return value is zero. To get extended error information, call GetLastError.

remarks.para: To differentiate the message that this function sends from messages sent by menus or controls, the high-order word of the wParam parameter of the WM_COMMAND or WM_SYSCOMMAND message contains the value 1.
Accelerator key combinations used to select items from the window menu are translated into WM_SYSCOMMAND messages; all other accelerator key combinations are translated into WM_COMMAND messages.
When TranslateAccelerator returns a nonzero value and the message is translated, the application should not use the TranslateMessage function to process the message again.
An accelerator need not correspond to a menu command.

If the accelerator command corresponds to a menu item, the application is sent WM_INITMENU and WM_INITMENUPOPUP messages, as if the user were trying to display the menu. However, these messages are not sent if any of the following conditions exist:

item.term: The accelerator key combination does not correspond to an item on the window menu and the window is minimized.
A mouse capture is in effect. For information about mouse capture, see the SetCapture function.

remarks.para: If the specified window is the active window and no window has the keyboard focus (which is generally the case if the window is minimized), TranslateAccelerator translates WM_SYSKEYUP and WM_SYSKEYDOWN messages instead of WM_KEYUP and WM_KEYDOWN messages.

If an accelerator keystroke occurs that corresponds to a menu item when the window that owns the menu is minimized, TranslateAccelerator does not send a WM_COMMAND message. However, if an accelerator keystroke occurs that does not match any of the items in the window's menu or in the window menu, the function sends a WM_COMMAND message, even if the window is minimized.
Examples
For an example, see Creating Accelerators for Font Attributes.

summary.para: Defines an accelerator key used in an accelerator table.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.User32.ACCEL.fVirt

member.summary: The accelerator identifier. This value is placed in the low-order word of the wParam parameter of the WM_COMMAND or WM_SYSCOMMAND message when the accelerator is pressed.

member.name: T:Vanara.PInvoke.User32.ButtonMessage
member.summary: Message identifiers used with the SendMessage function.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.User32.ButtonMessage.BM_GETCHECK
member.summary: Gets the check state of a radio button or check box. Return value is one of the values.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.User32.ButtonMessage.BM_SETCHECK
member.summary: Sets the check state of a radio button or check box. wParam is one of the values.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.User32.ButtonMessage.BM_GETSTATE
member.summary: Retrieves the state of a button or check box. Return value is one of the values.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.User32.ButtonMessage.BM_SETSTATE
member.summary: Sets the highlight state of a button. The highlight state indicates whether the button is highlighted as if the user had pushed it.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.User32.ButtonMessage.BM_SETSTYLE
member.summary: Sets the style of a button.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.User32.ButtonMessage.BM_CLICK
member.summary: Simulates the user clicking a button. This message causes the button to receive the WM_LBUTTONDOWN and WM_LBUTTONUP messages, and the button's parent window to receive a BN_CLICKED notification code.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.User32.ButtonMessage.BM_GETIMAGE
member.summary: Retrieves a handle to the image (icon or bitmap) associated with the button.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.User32.ButtonMessage.BM_SETIMAGE

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.User32.ButtonMessage.BM_SETDONTCLICK

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.User32.ButtonMessage.BCM_GETIDEALSIZE
member.summary: Gets the size of the button that best fits its text and image, if an image list is present.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.User32.ButtonMessage.BCM_SETIMAGELIST
member.summary: Assigns an image list to a button control.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.User32.ButtonMessage.BCM_GETTEXTMARGIN
